content: Identifying SPAM is usually done to prevent its appearance in the inbox. Since that is what you want, I suggest changing the workflow. Instead of flagging SPAM in Yahoo, do it in Thunderbird. Another approach would be to create a filter that moves SPAM into your inbox: that seems more likely what you want.

content:
General settings for each mail account.

  • 'Account Settings' > 'Composition & Addressing' for the account
  • Select 'Automatically quote the original message when replying'
  • Select 'Start my reply above the quote'

For that account do you have additional identities? If yes:

  • In 'Account Settings'
  • Select account name in left pane
  • click on 'Manage Identites' button
  • Select Identity and click on 'Edit'
  • Select 'Composition & Addressing' tab
  • Select 'Automatically quote the original message when replying'
  • Select 'Start my reply above the quote'
  • Click on 'OK
  • click on 'Close'


Check the following settings:

  • Menu icon > Settings > General
  • Scroll to bottom and click on 'Config Editor' button

Advanced Preferences opens in a new tab

  • In top search type: reply

For each identity - it will have idn where n = number : Look for lines that look like this:

  • 'mail.identity.id1.reply_on_top' Value should be 1

If an idn does not have a value of 1 then edit so it says 1

There is alo a default setting:

  • 'mail.identity.default.reply_on_top' Value by default is 0 (zero)

Suggest you alter that zero 0 to say number 1

  • click on the pencil icon located to the right
  • completely remove the 0 and type 1
  • the Pencil icon will change to a tick icon - click on it to save entry

In top search type: quote it will have idn where n = number : Look for the following lines that look like this:

  • mail.identity.id2.auto_quote Value should be 'true'

Also check the default:

  • mail.identity.default.auto_quote Value should be 'true'

content:
Yes, you can create an additional profile. A profile contains email accounts and all other settings that Thunderbird uses. You can have any number of profiles and can switch between them as desired. To create a new profile, click help>moretroubleshootinginformation, scroll down to Profiles, click 'about:profiles, then click 'create profiles' button, then next, then enter a name for the profile, e.g., hotmail, then click Finish. With that you will be in a new profile and can create your hotmail account.

Having written the above, you would generally be safe to add the hotmail account to existing profile, as Thunderbird keeps all accounts separate. For your protection, you could create a backup of the profile , either with tools>export (if your profile is smaller than 2 gig), or with the importexport addon.
creator: davidsk

content:
Do you have an email account, such as Gmail or Outlook, and want to use it with Thunderbird? You do need to have the email account first, and then use Thunderbird to manage it. Here are general steps: - be sure to use the standard release version, which is currently at version 102. (f what you downloaded is higher than 103, you may have downloaded the beta version). - when thunderbird starts, it prompts you for information on your email account. you need to have to set up the account, and that is provided to you by the website where you signed up for the email account. Thunderbird knows the settings for commonly used accounts, such as gmail. - you need to first decide whether you want the account set up as IMAP (all messages remain on the server) or as POP (messages are downloaded to PC). That is the first decision to be made in setting up the account. If you use the account from more than one device (such as PC and phone, or home PC and work PC), then IMAP is recommended.

Okay, from here on, you can ask questions for more specifics as you go.
creator: davidsk

content:
Maybe a problem with the index files.

  • Menu icon > Help > More Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' - half way - Profile Folders - click on 'Open Folder'

A new window opens showing the contents of your profile name folder.

  • Exit Thunderbird now - this is important

If POP account:

  • click on 'Mail' folder
  • click on 'pop account name' folder

Files that do NOT have any extension are mbox files and they contain emails - do not delete any of those mbox files.

  • Delete all the index files - they will have a *.msf extension.

If you have subfolders then you will see folders with a *.sbd extension

  • Select each *.sbd folder in turn and delete all the files that have a *.msf extension.

Start Thunderbird. All the index files will get recreated.

content: Subscribe only applies to IMAP accounts. POP accounts only create the Inbox on setup, and the Trash and Sent folders only appear after a message is deleted or sent. However, unsubscribing a folder sometimes doesn't work, such as with AOL accounts. Access the account in webmail and see if you can disable a setting like 'Show in IMAP' for the unwanted folders.
creator: sfhowes

content:
I edited my post while you were posting.

There is no webmail with these accounts. They're for a charity sight I volunteer for, with the email provided by a local cable company.

They're actually pop accounts according to the server settings in the account settings panel. Could that be wrong? The accounts wouldn't work if it was wrong, would they?
creator: jane.blue

content: Check the Server Type in Account Settings. IMAP ports are usually 993 or 143, while POP ports are 995 or 110. It's possible the Server Type and ports don't match. Note that the account type can't be changed just by changing the settings - the account has to be added again as a new account.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Aha! The accounts with fewer folders are port 110, but the accounts with the excess folders are port 143. Thanks, you've given me something to go on.

Thank you much!
creator: jane.blue

content: Each version of Thunderbird sees the account separately, being unaware of another copy also accessing the account. As such, it makes decisions assuming authority for the account.
creator: davidsk
